title: Ticket #3387: Can't remove EC2 jobs with invalid authentication.
description: Attempts to remove a job with invalid authentication will fail, as the job will go back on hold when RunInstances() or DescribeInstances() is called during recovery. Jaime suggests recording in the resource object, which can already tell if a ping failed because of an authentication failure, when such has happened, and, in the EC2 job object, checking before even entering the state machine [or at least before creating the client token] (but after waiting for the first ping to complete) if an authentication failure has occurred. If so, by never calling RunInstances() (and never creating a client token), we know that no instance could have been started, and it's safe not to record anything about the job -- allowing the schedd to remove it on its own.
remarks:
2013-Jan-10 14:01:01 by jfrey:
Code Review

  • Whether or not the first ping for a resource is done is already available to job objects via BaseJob::resourceStateKnown. We could replace resourceStateKnown with didFirstPing(), which is more space-efficient and easier to understand.

  • You don't need to set HoldReason in the job ad in the GM_INIT state. In GM_HOLD, the HoldReason will be taken from errorString if it's non-empty.

  • In the GM_INIT state, I don't believe you can go to GM_DELETE for all REMOVED jobs. We can end up orphaning instances and ssh keypairs.
